question: Question 2-6/27/2017 The reactor supervisor tells you that the K_eff for the reactor is 0.955. How much reactivity must you add to the reactor to reach criticality?

answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 3-6/27/2017 When performing rod calibrations, many facilities pull the rod out a given increment, then measure the time for reactor power to double (doubling time), then calculate the reactor period. If the doubling time is 42 seconds, what is the reactor period?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: ln (2) = -time/τ = time/(ln(2)) = 60.59 = 61 seconds
Incorrect. REF: ln (2) = -time/τ = time/(ln(2)) = 60.59 = 61 seconds
Correct.
Incorrect. REF: ln (2) = -time/τ = time/(ln(2)) = 60.59 = 61 seconds

question: Question 4-6/27/2017 A reactor has a shutdown margin of 0.0526 ∆K/K. Adding a reactor experiment increases the indicated count rate from 10 cps to 20 cps. Which one of the following is the new Keff of the reactor?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volume 2, Module 4, Enabling Objective 3.6, p. 28. SDM = 1-Keff/Keff → Keff = 1/SDM + 1 → Keff = 1/0.0526 + 1 → Keff = .95 CR1/CR2 = (1 - Keff2) / (1 - Keff1) → 10/20 = (1 - Keff2) / (1 - 0.95) (0.5) x (0.05) = (1 - Keff2) → Keff2 = 1 - (0.5)(0.05) = 0.975

Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volume 2, Module 4, Enabling Objective 3.6, p. 28. SDM = 1-Keff/Keff → Keff = 1/SDM + 1 → Keff = 1/0.0526 + 1 → Keff = .95 CR1/CR2 = (1 - Keff2) / (1 - Keff1) → 10/20 = (1 - Keff2) / (1 - 0.95) (0.5) x (0.05) = (1 - Keff2) → Keff2 = 1 - (0.5)(0.05) = 0.975
Correct.

Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory Volume 2, Module 4, Enabling Objective 3.6, p. 28. SDM = 1-Keff/Keff → Keff = 1/SDM + 1 → Keff = 1/0.0526 + 1 → Keff = .95 CR1/CR2 = (1 - Keff2) / (1 - Keff1) → 10/20 = (1 - Keff2) / (1 - 0.95) (0.5) x (0.05) = (1 - Keff2) → Keff2 = 1 - (0.5)(0.05) = 0.975

question: Question 6-6/27/2017 WHICH ONE of the following describes the MAJOR contributions to the production and depletion of xenon in the reactor?

answers.answer: a. Produced directly from fission and depletes by neutron absorption only.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: b. Produced from radioactive decay of iodine and depletes by neutron absorption only.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: c. Produced directly from fission and depletes by radioactive decay and neutron absorption.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, §

answers.answer: d. Produced from radioactive decay of iodine and depletes by radioactive decay and neutron absorption.
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 7-6/27/2017 The probability of neutron interaction per cm of travel in a material is defined as:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 2.5.2, page 2-44.
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 2.5.2, page 2-44.
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Section 2.5.2, page 2-44.
Correct.

question: Question 8-6/27/2017 Which ONE of the following conditions would INCREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Lowering moderator temperature if the moderator temperature coefficient is negative.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.

answers.answer: b. Inserting an experiment adding positive reactivity.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.

answers.answer: c. Depletion of a burnable poison.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 6.2.3, p. 6-4.
Correct.

question: Question 9-6/27/2017 Which one of the following is the PRIMARY reason that delayed neutrons are so effective at controlling reactor power?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons make up a very large fraction of the fission neutrons in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons have a much longer mean lifetime than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons are born at lower energies than prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons are born at thermal energies.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, §§ 3.2.2 — 3.2.3

question: Question 10-6/27/2017 Which one of the following is a correct statement concerning the factors affecting control rod worth?

answers.answer: a. As reactor power increases rod worth increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: b. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth for periphery rods to decrease.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: c. Fuel burn up causes the rod worth to increase in the center of the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, § 7.2 & 7.3, pp. 7-1 — 7-10.

answers.answer: d. The withdrawal of a rod causes the rod worth of the remaining inserted rods to increase.
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 11-6/27/2017 Pool temperature increases by 20°F. Given αT moderator = -0.0005 ∆K/K/°F and an average regulating rod worth of 0.004 ∆K/K/inch. By how much and in what direction did the regulating rod move to compensate for the temperature change?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: +20°F × -0.0005 ∆K/K/°F = - 0.01 ∆K/K. To compensate the rod must add +0.01 ∆K/K. +0.01∆K/K ÷ +0.004 ∆K/K/inch = +2.5 inches
Incorrect. REF: +20°F × -0.0005 ∆K/K/°F = - 0.01 ∆K/K. To compensate the rod must add +0.01 ∆K/K. +0.01∆K/K ÷ +0.004 ∆K/K/inch = +2.5 inches
Incorrect. REF: +20°F × -0.0005 ∆K/K/°F = - 0.01 ∆K/K. To compensate the rod must add +0.01 ∆K/K. +0.01∆K/K ÷ +0.004 ∆K/K/inch = +2.5 inches
Correct.

question: Question 12-6/27/2017 You perform two startups with exactly the same core characteristics. During the first startup you proceed straight to criticality. During the second startup you receive a phone call after starting to pull rods, but before reaching criticality. How will this increase in time before reaching criticality affect reactor critical conditions? For the second startup

answers.answer: a. rod height will be the same, reactor power will be the same.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 5.3

answers.answer: b. rod height will be the same, reactor power will be higher.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. rod height will be higher, reactor power will be higher.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 5.3

answers.answer: d. rod height will be lower, reactor power will be lower.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, § 5.3

question: Question 13-6/27/2017 A reactor is subcritical with a Keff of 0.955. Which ONE of the following is the MINIMUM reactivity (K/K) that must be added to produce prompt criticality? Given βeff=0.007

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: From k=0.995 to criticality (k=1), Δ = (k-1)/k = -0.047 )k/k or 0.047 )k/k needs to be added to reach criticality. From criticality to JUST prompt, Δ = βeff is required, so minimum reactivity = 0.047+0.007= 0.054

Incorrect. REF: From k=0.995 to criticality (k=1), Δ = (k-1)/k = -0.047 )k/k or 0.047 )k/k needs to be added to reach criticality. From criticality to JUST prompt, Δ = βeff is required, so minimum reactivity = 0.047+0.007= 0.054
Correct.

Incorrect. REF: From k=0.995 to criticality (k=1), Δ = (k-1)/k = -0.047 )k/k or 0.047 )k/k needs to be added to reach criticality. From criticality to JUST prompt, Δ = βeff is required, so minimum reactivity = 0.047+0.007= 0.054

question: Question 14-6/27/2017 The ratio of the number of neutrons in one generation to the number of neutrons in the previous generation defines the:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 3.3
Incorrect. REF: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 3.3
Incorrect. REF: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 3.3
Correct.

question: Question 15-6/27/2017 Which ONE of the following does NOT affect the Effective Multiplication Factor K_eff?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 3, pages 2-9.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 3, pages 2-9.

answers.answer: c. The physical dimensions of the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module 3, pages 2-9.

answers.answer: d. The strength of an installed neutron souce.
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 17-6/27/2017 You’ve just increased power at a research reactor. As a result fuel temperature increased from 100°C to 120°C. For this reactor the fuel temperature coefficient (αtf) is -0.01% k/k/°C, and the average rod worth for the regulating rod is 0.05% )k/k/inch. How far and in what direction must you move the regulating rod to compensate? (Assume all other factors which could affect reactivity remain unchanged.)

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory -0.0001)k/k/°C Η +20°C = -0.002)k/k. To compensate must add +0.002)k/k. (0.002)k/k) ) (0.0005%)k/k/inch) = 4 inches in the positive (outward) direction.

Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory -0.0001)k/k/°C Η +20°C = -0.002)k/k. To compensate must add +0.002)k/k. (0.002)k/k) ) (0.0005%)k/k/inch) = 4 inches in the positive (outward) direction.

Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory -0.0001)k/k/°C Η +20°C = -0.002)k/k. To compensate must add +0.002)k/k. (0.002)k/k) ) (0.0005%)k/k/inch) = 4 inches in the positive (outward) direction.
Correct.

question: Question 18-6/27/2017 Several processes occur that may increase or decrease the available number of neutrons. SELECT from the following the six-factor formula term that describes an INCREASE in the number of neutrons during the cycle.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Correct.

question: Question 19-6/27/2017 Which of the following atoms will cause a neutron to lose the most energy during an elastic scattering reaction?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory
Correct.

question: Question 20-6/27/2017 A reactor is operating at a constant power level with equilibrium xenon. Reactor power is then doubled. The equilibrium xenon level at the higher power level will be:

answers.answer: a. higher than its value at the lower power level, but not twice as high.
answers.feedback: Correct.
Incorrect. REF: DOE Reference, Module 3, Xenon, page 37

answers.answer: c. more than twice as high.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Reference, Module 3, Xenon, page 37

answers.answer: d. the same as at the lower power level.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Reference, Module 3, Xenon, page 37
